_link.title: I can use a voltmeter correctly to measure potential difference

toLevel2.question: How must a voltmeter be connected in a circuit to measure potential difference?
What physical quantity does a voltmeter measure?
What is the unit displayed on a voltmeter?
A voltmeter compares which quantity entering and leaving a component?
Which circuit symbol represents a voltmeter?
A voltmeter must be connected in {{parallel}} across a component to measure potential difference.
A voltmeter measures potential difference in {{volts}} and has very {{high}} resistance.
The voltmeter reading tells us how much {{energy}} each coulomb of {{charge}} transfers.
A voltmeter is connected in parallel with the component being measured.
A voltmeter should be connected in series like an ammeter.

toLevel3.question: Why must a voltmeter have very high internal resistance?
options: To prevent it from drawing significant current from the circuit
To protect the component being measured
To make the reading more visible
toLevel3.answer: To prevent it from drawing significant current from the circuit

toLevel3.question: A voltmeter reads 6 V across a resistor. What does this mean?
options: Each coulomb of charge loses 6 J of energy in the resistor
6 A of current flows through the resistor
6 C of charge flows per second
toLevel3.answer: Each coulomb of charge loses 6 J of energy in the resistor

toLevel3.question: What would happen if a voltmeter were accidentally connected in series?
options: Very little current would flow because of the voltmeter's high resistance
The voltmeter would give a more accurate reading
toLevel3.answer: Very little current would flow because of the voltmeter's high resistance

toLevel3.question: When measuring the potential difference across a battery, where should the voltmeter probes be placed?
options: One probe on each terminal of the battery
Both probes on the positive terminal
Both probes on the negative terminal
One probe on the battery, one on a resistor
toLevel3.answer: One probe on each terminal of the battery

toLevel3.question: Why is measuring potential difference important for circuit analysis?
options: It shows how much energy each coulomb transfers to or from a component
It directly measures the power used
It tells us the total charge in the circuit
It measures the speed of electrons
toLevel3.answer: It shows how much energy each coulomb transfers to or from a component

toLevel3.question: A student measures 0 V across a wire in a working circuit. What does this indicate?
options: Negligible energy is transferred in the wire
toLevel3.answer: Negligible energy is transferred in the wire

toLevel3.question: A voltmeter has very {{high}} resistance so it draws minimal {{current}} from the circuit.
To measure the potential difference across a lamp, connect the voltmeter in {{parallel}} with the {{lamp}}.
If a voltmeter reads 12 V, each {{coulomb}} of charge transfers {{12}} joules of energy.
A voltmeter with low resistance would affect the circuit by drawing significant current.

toLevel4.question: A circuit has three resistors in series with a 12 V supply. A student measures 4 V, 5 V, and 3 V across them respectively. Is this measurement consistent?
options: Yes, because 4 + 5 + 3 = 12 V equals the supply voltage
No, the readings should all be equal
No, the total should be less than 12 V
Yes, but only if resistors are equal
toLevel4.answer: Yes, because 4 + 5 + 3 = 12 V equals the supply voltage

toLevel4.question: A digital voltmeter has 10 MΩ internal resistance. If measuring a 10 kΩ resistor in a circuit, what percentage of circuit current does it draw?
In a parallel circuit, a student measures the same voltage (6 V) across each of three different resistors. Is this expected?
options: Yes, components in parallel have the same potential difference
No, voltage should be different for each resistor
Only if the resistors have equal values
Only if current is the same through each
toLevel4.answer: Yes, components in parallel have the same potential difference

toLevel4.question: A voltmeter is connected correctly across a resistor and reads 8 V. If the resistor carries 2 A, how much energy does the resistor transfer per second?
A technician needs to measure a 100 mV signal accurately. What type of voltmeter specification is most important?
options: High sensitivity and high input resistance
toLevel4.answer: High sensitivity and high input resistance

toLevel4.question: When measuring potential difference across a cell in a series circuit, the reading is 1.4 V. When the cell is disconnected, it reads 1.5 V. What causes this difference?
options: Internal resistance of the cell causes a voltage drop when current flows
toLevel4.answer: Internal resistance of the cell causes a voltage drop when current flows

toLevel4.question: A student connects a voltmeter across two points in a circuit and gets a negative reading. What does this indicate?
options: The voltmeter probes are connected in reverse polarity
toLevel4.answer: The voltmeter probes are connected in reverse polarity

toLevel4.question: In a series circuit with 9 V supply, if V₁ = 3 V and V₂ = 4 V, then V₃ = {{2}} V to satisfy Vsupply = V₁ + V₂ + V₃.
A voltmeter reading of 5 V across a 10 Ω resistor indicates a current of I = V/R = {{0.5}} A and power of P = VI = {{2.5}} W.
The ideal voltmeter has {{infinite}} resistance so it draws {{zero}} current from the circuit.

toLevel5.question: A voltmeter with 1 MΩ internal resistance is used to measure voltage across a 1 MΩ resistor. What is the effect on the reading?
options: The reading is lower than the actual voltage by approximately half
The reading is higher than actual
toLevel5.answer: The reading is lower than the actual voltage by approximately half

toLevel5.question: An engineer measures 11.5 V across a component in a 12 V circuit. The battery has internal resistance. What can be concluded?
options: 0.5 V is dropped across the internal resistance of the battery
The component has 0.5 V extra from somewhere
toLevel5.answer: 0.5 V is dropped across the internal resistance of the battery

toLevel5.question: Two voltmeters measure the same point in a circuit. Meter A (10 MΩ) reads 5.00 V. Meter B (100 kΩ) reads 4.85 V. Which reading is more accurate and why?
options: Meter A, because higher resistance causes less loading effect
Meter B, because lower resistance gives better contact
toLevel5.answer: Meter A, because higher resistance causes less loading effect

toLevel5.question: A student argues that since a voltmeter is in parallel, adding it shouldn't affect the circuit. Under what conditions is this argument most valid?
options: When the voltmeter resistance is much higher than the circuit resistance
When the voltmeter resistance equals the circuit resistance
When measuring DC but not AC
When the circuit has high current
toLevel5.answer: When the voltmeter resistance is much higher than the circuit resistance

toLevel5.question: In a voltage divider with two 10 kΩ resistors and 10 V supply, the theoretical output is 5 V. A voltmeter with 100 kΩ resistance measures the output. What will it read?
A precision voltage measurement requires accuracy to 0.01 V in a high-impedance circuit. What voltmeter characteristic is most critical?
options: Input impedance of at least 10× the circuit impedance
toLevel5.answer: Input impedance of at least 10× the circuit impedance

toLevel5.question: A battery's terminal voltage is measured as 11.8 V under load and 12.4 V at no load. If the load draws 3 A, what is the battery's internal resistance?
A complex circuit has multiple parallel branches. A student measures different voltages at the same nodes using a low-quality voltmeter. What is the most likely cause?
options: The voltmeter's resistance varies with range, causing different loading effects
The student is making connection errors
toLevel5.answer: The voltmeter's resistance varies with range, causing different loading effects

toLevel5.question: A voltmeter with 1 MΩ resistance measuring across a 1 MΩ resistor forms a parallel combination of {{500}} kΩ, reducing the voltage reading to approximately {{half}}.
To minimise loading error, the voltmeter resistance should be at least {{10}} times greater than the {{resistance}} being measured.
